triplets: Steamed filled bun originating from Chinese cuisine, classified as a type of food
Eating as a snack, breakfast item, or part of a meal
Wheat flour dough for the bun exterior and various fillings such as meat, vegetables, or sweet pastes
Dough that forms the outer bun and holds the filling inside
Filling made from meat, vegetables, or sweet ingredients depending on the type
Typically white due to steamed dough, sometimes slightly yellowish or brown depending on ingredients or baking variations
Chinese cuisine, dim sum menus, street food offerings, and snack culture
Various restaurants, street vendors, and commercial food producers specializing in steamed buns
Approximately 50–150 grams per piece depending on size and filling
Approximately 5–8 cm, varying with type and preparation
Short-lived; typically consumed fresh within a few hours after steaming, or up to 1–2 days if refrigerated and reheated
